section.title: 4.2 Common Request Headers
section.p: Many operations accept request headers. This section provides an overview of each request header. Consult the specific operation to determine if the header applies to the operation and any other notes that are of interest.

section.title: 4.2.1 Accept
section.p: Where applicable, this determines how the response body is formatted. For example, you can use this to list the objects in a container as:

ul.li: text (text/plain)
JSON (application/json)
XML (text/xml, application/xml)

section.title: 4.2.2 Content-Length
section.p: Where applicable, this is the length in bytes of the body of the request. For objects, you may use the Transfer-Encoding instead of a Content-Length.

section.title: 4.2.3 Content-Type
section.p: Where applicable, this indicates the MIME type of an object.

When applied to object resources, the Content-Type request header is optional. If not specified, Object Storage will attempt to identify the content type and assign a MIME type. If this fails, the type is set to application/octet-stream. If you specify a value in the request header, when you next do a HEAD or GET operation on the object, the Content-Type response header is set to the specified value.

section.title: 4.2.4 Date
section.p: When specified, this is the date and time at which the operation request is made. The value should be expressed as shown in one of the following examples:
section.codeblock: Sun, 06 Nov 1994 08:49:37 +0000 ; RFC 2822 Sun, 06 Nov 1994 08:49:37 GMT ; RFC 822, updated by RFC 1123 Sunday, 06-Nov-94 08:49:37 GMT ; RFC 850, obsoleted by RFC 1036 Sun Nov 6 08:49:37 1994 ; ANSI C's asctime() format
section.p: As you can see, the date and time is expressed in GMT or UTC time. The first example ("Sun, 06 Nov 1994 08:49:37 +0000") is the preferred format. However, Object Storage uses the second example ("Sun, 06 Nov 1994 08:49:37 GMT") when displaying dates.

section.title: 4.2.5 X-Auth-Token
section.p: When specified, this identifies the user making the request. In addition, if this token is being used by a user with Admin privilege level, the token must be scoped to the project associated with the account. If no token is specified, the request will fail unless you have been granted access to the resource by some other mechanism such as ACLs. See Using Authentication Tokens for more information about tokens.

section.title: 4.2.6 X-Container-Meta-{name}
section.p: This allows you to set custom metadata on a container using a header name with a prefix of X-Container-Meta-. After this prefix, you can pick any name meaningful to you. For example, X-Container-Meta-Reviewed could be used indicate that the contents of a container had been reviewed.
Any valid UTF-8 http header value is allowed for metadata, however we recommend that you URL-encode any non-ASCII values

section.title: 4.2.7 X-Container-Read
section.p: Sets the access control list (ACL) that grants read access to a container and its objects.

section.title: 4.2.8 X-Container-Write
section.p: Sets the access control list (ACL) that grants write access to a container and its objects.

section.title: 4.2.9 ETag
section.p: Object Storage does not use the Content-MD5 request header - use ETag as a request header instead. Use this header to ensure that an upload of an object does not suffer from a data corruption.
For objects smaller than 5GB and manifest objects, this is the MD5 checksum of the request body.
See End to end integrity for more information.

section.title: 4.2.10 X-Account-Meta-{name}
section.p: This allows you to set custom metadata on an account using a header name with a prefix of X-Account-Meta-. After this prefix, you can pick any name meaningful to you.

section.title: 4.2.11 X-Remove-Account-Meta-{name}
section.p: This allows you to remove custom metadata on an account using a headers name with a prefix of X-Account-Meta-. After this prefix, you specify the metadata item you wish to remove.

section.title: 4.2.12 X-Object-Meta-{name}
section.p: This allows you to set custom metadata on an object using a header name with a prefix of X-Object-Meta-. After this prefix, you can pick any name meaningful to you.

section.title: 4.3.1 Date
section.p: When supplied, the Date header is the time of the operation expressed in GMT (effectively UTC) as shown in the following example:
section.codeblock: HTTP/1.1 200 OK Date: Sun, 06 Nov 1994 08:49:37 GMT

section.title: 4.3.2 Last-Modified
section.p: This is the date and time that the container or object was created or the last time that the metadata was changed.

section.title: 4.3.3 Content-Length
section.p: When the response includes a body, this indicates the length of the body in bytes.

lq.p: Note: For HEAD operations against an object, the Content-Length response header contains the size of the object. Normally, in HTTP HEAD operations, the Content-Length would be zero since no content is returned. This exception might confuse your client if it waits for more content in the response.

section.title: 4.3.4 Content-Type
section.p: When the response includes a body, this indicates the MIME type of the response. For listing operations (account/container), you can use the Accept request header to request JSON or XML. For a GET or HEAD against an object, the Content-Type is whatever value was set when the object was uploaded.

section.title: 4.3.5 X-Container-Meta-{name}
section.p: This contains the value of X-Container-Meta-{name} metadata that was previously set on a container, where {name} is an arbitrary name meaningful to you.

section.title: 4.3.6 X-Account-Object-Count
section.p: The total number of objects in all containers associated with the account.

section.title: 4.3.7 X-Account-Bytes-Used
section.p: The total size in bytes of all objects in all containers associated with the account.

section.title: 4.3.8 X-Account-Container-Count
section.p: The number of containers in the account

section.title: 4.3.9 X-Container-Read
section.p: The access control list (ACL) that grants read access to a container and its objects.

section.title: 4.3.10 X-Container-Write
section.p: The access control list (ACL) that grants write access to a container and its objects.

section.title: 4.3.11 X-Container-Object-Count
section.p: The number of objects in the container.

section.title: 4.3.12 X-Container-Bytes-Used
section.p: The total number of bytes used by all objects in the container.

section.title: 4.3.13 ETag
section.p: For objects smaller than 5GB and manifest objects, this is the MD5 checksum of the response body.

For manifest objects, this is the MD5 checksum of the concatenated string of MD5 checksums/ETags for each of the segments in the manifest - not the MD5 checksum of the content that was downloaded. Also the value is enclosed in double-quote characters.
See End to end integrity for more information.

section.title: 4.3.14 X-Account-Meta-{name}
section.p: This contains the value of X-Account-Meta-{name} metadata that was previously set on an account, where {name} is an arbitrary name meaningful to you.

section.title: 4.3.15 X-Object-Meta-{name}
section.p: This contains the value of X-Object-Meta-{name} metadata that was previously set on an object, where {name} is an arbitrary name meaningful to you.

section.title: 4.3.16 X-Static-Large-Object
section.p: If present and set to true, it indicates that this is a static object manifest. See Static Large Object Creation for more information.

section.p: Retrieve the contents of an object.

li.p: You can perform conditional GET requests by using certain HTTP headers as documented in [RFC 2616](http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2616.txt](http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2616.txt). See Conditional GET of objects for more information.
It is also possible to fetch a portion of data using basic support of the HTTP Range header.

If the object has the X-Static-Large-Object set to true, you may add the ?multipart-manifest=get query string to the request. This causes the manifest to be downloaded instead of the concatenated segment objects.

section.title: PUT /v1/{project_id}/{container}/{object}
section.p: Creates an object with the supplied data content and metadata.
You also use this operation to update an existing object (i.e. PUT to the same object name twice). You should think of this as replacing the previous object's content and metadata.
In its simplest form, the PUT operation creates or replaces an existing object with up to 5GB of data content. However, there are other features available as follows:

li.p: You can upload object content in chunks. This allows you to start an upload before you know the total size of the object. You use the Transfer-Encoding request header and omit the Content-Length request header.

For objects greater than 5GB, you can upload a number of object segments. When all segments are uploaded, you upload a manifest object telling Object Storage how to find the segments of the large object. See Large Object Creation for more information.

You can create Pseudo-Hierarchical Folders or Directories. For a pseudo folder or directory, a good practice is to create a zero-sized placeholder object with a Content-Type of "application/directory".

You can use the Content-Encoding request header to indicate that the object contents are compressed without losing the identity of the underlying media type of the file as specified by the Content-Type request header.
You can override a browser's default behavior for a file so that the downloader saves the file rather than displaying it using default browser settings by setting the Content-Disposition.

You can ensure end-to-end data integrity by including an MD5 checksum of your object's data in the ETag header. You are not required to include the ETag header, but it is recommended to ensure that the storage system successfully stored your object's content. See End to end integrity for more information.

You can set custom metadata on an object using a header name with a prefix of X-Object-Meta-. After this prefix, you can pick any name meaningful to you. For example, X-Object-Meta-Reviewed could be used indicate that the contents of an object had been reviewed. Any valid UTF-8 http header value is allowed for metadata, however we recommend that you URL-encode any non-ASCII values.
You can preserve prior versions of an object by enabling object versioning on the container. See Object Versioning for more information.

ul.li: X-Auth-Token - Optional - Authentication token
Authorization - Optional - Use Signature Based Authentication instead of X-Auth-Token

Transfer-Encoding - Optional - Allows upload of an object in "chunks".

Content-Encoding - Optional - Indicate that the contents are compressed

section.title: COPY /v1/{project_id}/{source-container}/{source-object}
section.p: Creates an object using another object as the source for the content and metadata. Using an existing object means that the content is copied inside the Object Storage service (i.e., at the server side). This means that the operation will be quicker because you do not need to transfer the object contents over the public internet. In addition, you will not be charged for any network transfer of the object contents (however, you may be charged for the operation itself).

lq.p: Note: When you copy a manifest object, the new object is a "normal" object -- not a copy of the manifest. Instead it is a concatenation of all the segment objects. This means that you cannot copy objects larger than 5GB in size.

section.p: The target container must exist before you perform the copy object operation.

All metadata is preserved during the object copy. If you specify metadata on the request to copy the object (either the PUT or the COPY), the metadata overwrites any conflicting keys on the target (new) object.

You can pick any name that is meaningful to you. However, see Container and Object Naming for restrictions on container names. In addition, the target and source object names may be the same name. This allows you to change the metadata of individual items without having to specify the values of all the other metadata items in the request.
The path specifies the account, container name and object name of either the source or target object as follows:

li.p: PUT -- the container and object names are the name of the new object. The following request headers must be set:

ul.li: X-Copy-From - this designates the source of the data. The header value must be the container and object name of the source object in the form of "/{container}/{object}". The container and object names must be UTF-8 encoded and then URL-encoded.
Content-Length - this must be present and set to a value of zero (0).

li.p: COPY -- the container and object names are the names of an existing object. The following request header must be set:

ul.li: Destination - this designates the target of the operation. The value must be the container and object name of the new (target) object in the form of "/{container}/{object}".

section.p: The following request headers apply to both PUT and COPY operations.

ul.li: X-Auth-Token - Optional - Authentication token
Authorization - Optional - Use Signature Based Authentication instead of X-Auth-Token
Content-Type - Optional - Specifies a new Content-Type for the new object
Content-Encoding - Optional - Indicate that the contents are compressed
Content-Disposition - Optional - Override default download behaviour of browsers
X-Object-Meta-{name} - Optional - Sets custom metadata on an object

section.p: None.
This operation does not require a request body.
On success, the object is created.
See HTTP Status Codes for more information.
No response body is returned. The following response headers are returned:

ul.li: X-Copied-From - the name of the container/object used as source for the new object
X-Copied-From-Last-Modified - the time and date that the source object was last updated

section.p: If an error occurs, the response body contains a description of the error.
See HTTP Status Codes for more information.

curl -i -k -X COPY -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H 'Accept: application/json' -H 'X-Auth-Token: {Auth_Token}' -H 'Destination: {container}/{object}' {BaseURI}/v1/{project_id}/{container}/{object}

section.p: The POST operation is used in two modes: * Updates the metadata of an object. This is the operation documented here. * FormPOST. With specific query parameters, the POST operaiton allows you to upload files directly into Object Storage by using signature-based authentication. See FormPOST for more information about this mode.
You cannot use the POST operation to change any of the following metadata:

All existing metadata, with the exception of Content-Type is overwritten by the POST operation. This means you must specify all of the metadata in the request. For example, if an object already has a Content-Encoding of gzip and you plan to also set X-Object-Meta-One, both must be specified in a single request. If you only set X-Container-Meta-One, when you later do a HEAD operation, only X-Container-Meta-One would exist -- in effect Content-Encoding is lost.
However, Content-Type is unchanged (unless included in the request). You cannot use the Content-Length request header since the object content is not changed by this operation.
A POST operation with no metadata changes will cause all the metadata with the exception of Content-Type, Content-Length, ETag and Last-Modified to be cleared.
An easier way to change object metadata is to use the Copy Object operation since it only changes metadata that you update in the request.
